body:

I've got Sept 40s which are now ITM for NTAP and Sept 15s for NTNX.

That way I can ride 2 earnings if they are really bad.

author: Fathers85
body:
T2 biosystems, Ticker TTOO, or Tendie2 for you Autists. 53 cent play that will most likely get a piece of 25 billion towards testing in PPP passed today

          - T2 recently signed an agreement with Hackensack to convert their FDA approved rapid COVID test for the FDA approved T2Dx platform.
         - US Government is their largest customer 
         - In the last year, T2 has received  FDA "breakthrough" designation, BARDA contract, NTAP from medicare, and CE approval.
          - The machine is likely to produce the most accurate testing on the market given tests available right now. 
         - Can complete 14 whole blood samples in 1-3 hour
         - New CEO and product Rep Group
         - Horrible past execution and terrible balance sheet. But don’t think that matters near term.

author: Sarkham89
body:
I agree with most of this. Although, It’s skewed to be negative. Businesses expenses being used as a complaint to counter marketshare gains? JCP will be a good stock option for you, as there business expenses will be zero by end of year. 

I wouldn’t ever consider buying ZM, but I want to point out that AMZN wasn’t profitable for several years the company existed. I remember in 2012 it had a P/E over 3500. At around 250 it would that would have been a great investment. 

COST just reported 1.5 billion YOY revenue increase for March. I think that this leans in the direction of it’s not merely e-commerce. 

Disney+ (DIS) reported recently it has over 50 million subscribers as of 2 months ago being around 20. 

Working from home requires additional security. You are vastly under playing the business required for this. Home based networks can make confidential information more vulnerable. PAWN and CSCO both stand to benefit from this. (Carbonite mcafee, etc). There is also additional companies that help provide a safe portal (NTAP, CSCO, MSFT) to access the infrastructure. The servers networks need built (INTC, AMD, NVDA) and then stored (DLR). Then maintained (JNPR CSCO). 

Beyond al of that Stock market is speculative. I speculate this is a great country and we have great people in this country that will pull through and make it a better place to live. 

Good luck to you sir, you are your family stay safe.

author: biochemguy
body:
I am long NVDA.  I have been following the role of machine learning and deep learning in productivity improvements and automation.  NVDA has the gold standard chipset for this use, and is greatly benefiting from this revolution.    


Generally I never invest in manufacturing, and stay away from chip makers.  But this trend is too strong.  So I'm long NVDA, and your only hope is an overall market drop.  If the market trades sideways or up, you are going to be a retard with less money.

author: Fortune_Fus1on
body:
Low end and mid end graphics cards will become obsolete in the coming years because APU's will be good enough to replace them. So nVidia will likely be pushed out of the market there because APUs are a product they can't compete with. 

Right now nVidia only has one main competitor which is AMD, who are too busy drooling on the floor to actually bring them pain, but both Intel and ARM are also entering the market.

On the long term AI algorithms will completely replace traditional game engines which will in turn make GPU's as we know it obsolete, my point in the original comment. Now nVidia are very well positioned to take advantage of this but there is no guarantee they will be the only players in this field, in fact I expect the software guys to come and steal their lunch because: 

1) Game publishers are rich as fuck and have all the money necessary to create this AI hardware divisions
2) Epic Games who own Unreal Engine are 49% owned by Tencent and China has been ramping up their own silicon lately, and I can guarantee they will not miss this chance of controlling PC gaming hardware

Basically nVidia's pie will continue to dwindle on the PC gaming and their growth on emergent markets will also be capped pretty soon.

Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk

author: LifeInAction
body:
It depends, I'm thinking about both actually specifically since they're both somewhat high risk, moving in huge waves right now, figured I'd spread out, so if one drops, I can hopefully have the other to fall back on to hopefully have some reasonable amount of gains. 

Back when everyone was dabbling between AMD and Nvidia, the tech chip stocks, I put all into Nvidia and did end up getting gains, but realized I of course would've gotten significantly more in AMD. There was no way to predict it, so the real smart decision learned would've been to just spread out a bit, and split my cash into both, so if one does particular well, I can at least average and balance with the other. Balancing with BA and DAL is now for similar reason, except these are even higher risk, since they'll either plummet or soar to the moon.

author: Figurativelyryan
body:
I don't favour one brand over the other, they both make decent stuff, I just feel that AMD are in a slightly stronger position.

Data centers AMD lag behind, definitely. But the current Nvidia market share isn't likely to grow in the short term - if anything AMD are still slowly chipping away at it.

I wouldn't gamble on stimulus cheques equating directly to huge sales of high-end graphics cards either, not saying it won't happen, but I certainly wouldn't risk my tendies on Nvidia over it.

The current crop of Radeon driver issues were largely ironed out just before the wu-flu went ballistic, but it's a wildcard - I wouldn't know how to factor that into consumer confidence.

author: KushwalkerDankstar
body: They’re a global data center supplier, what makes you think they aren’t raking in the cash from orders worldwide? You KNOW the increase internet traffic will force more focus on high end equipment, and NVIDIA has that market by a chokehold.

author: Winston_The_Pig
body:
So I wanted to start trading this year fresh. Made some really big wins on retarded fd’s on Tesla, bynd, Spce, as well as many retarded day trades. My scheme was to make $1k bets on companies that I thought were getting short squeezed/meme’d. 

The first massive downie was from getting sooo close to $25k that I went full retard in the days of pokimane and had about $15k in Msft and nvidia calls. 

Came back up when I decided to be a gay bear on rcl, dal, Wynn, spy,

Lost about 60% of my account on my first work at home day - drinking and averaging down on the witching hour (started out as a $500 dumb bet that I knew was dumb but I still kept averaging down until I stupidly had $13k into the position). 

On a side note during this time my rollover ira has gone from $6k to $20k - bought the same bear positions but didn’t use any of that money on the witching shit.
